markups: ''Player communicating within a game world's diegesis in a thematically appropriate way.''

Players of games often enact actions in game worlds as well as engage in conversations with other players or game entities. <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> occurs when players take part of conversations as inhabitants of those game worlds and do so without referring to things that do not belong to the specific game worlds.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Storytelling%20System">Storytelling System</link></style> encourages players to roleplay by speaking as their characters but this is difficult to do consistency since players and game masters need to discuss rules sometimes. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massive Multiplayer</link></style> versions such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eve%20Online">Eve Online</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> automate rules and most game masters' tasks but players may still need to talk to each other about rules and thereby cannot always use <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style>. Single-player <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer Roleplaying Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Arcanum:%20Of%20Steamworks%20and%20Magick%20Obscura">Arcanum</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Witcher%20series">Witcher series</link></style>, can avoid this through using dialogue systems where players.

Most games allow players to engage in non-diegetic communication simply because they can say whatever they want either face-to-face or due to the fact that the communication channels provided to them allows this type of communication as well.

The design goal of <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> is often not to make it the only form of communication in a game but to encourage it to the best possible level and ensure that different types of communication do not interfere with each other. Per its definition, <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> is not compatible with <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> and designing for each is largely a case of minimizing the other of compartmentalizing them. Also given by its definition, <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> is a way of affecting how players communicate through their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (since some diegetic entity must be doing the actual communicating in the diegesis). This typically means that <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> and <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style> can be problematic to combine since players must handle shifts between the two types of communication to not break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> can both provide a medium for players to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style>, and by providing several players can more easily police themselves to keep specific ones reserved for <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style>. <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> is a special case of this where the game systems can ensure that all communication is diegetic.

Having <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> is often seen as something that improves <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style> typically requires talking between players, and having this as <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> is in contrast seen as one of the main features of the gaming style. For this type of gaming <style="Link"><link="meta-techniques">Meta-Techniques</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="meta-postures">Meta-Postures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="prompting-techniques">Prompting Techniques</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="substitute-actions">Substitute Actions</link></style> exist which provide extra <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> to players and can thereby keep normal conversation as <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Diegetic%20Patterns">Diegetic Pattern</link></style> and designing for it is strongly related to designing for <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.

For games with <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> may often mean ensuring <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/In%20Character%20Conversations">In Character Conversations</link></style>.

While having <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> helps having <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>, it also helps having <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> can put a twist on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> but also limit it if players find doing the <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Communication</style> difficult or uncomfortable.
